case_vignette: A 17-year-old girl comes to the primary care clinic with her father complaining of right knee pain. She reports that the pain started about a month ago, and since then it has gotten progressively worse. The knee pain is not constant but becomes most noticeable when going up or down the stairs. She also endorses that her knee becomes uncomfortable towards the end of class. Her father is worried because the pain is affecting her ability to play basketball, and she has college scouts coming to watch her play. The patient has no chronic medical conditions. She had a tonsillectomy as a child. She takes a multivitamin and uses ibuprofen as needed for the pain. On physical examination, there is tenderness at the inferior pole of the patella, without swelling or overlying skin changes.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I'm having pain in my right knee that gets worse when I go up or down stairs and it feels uncomfortable towards the end of class.
Have you had any knee pain before?
No, this started about a month ago and it's gotten progressively worse since then.
Have you recently injured your knee or taken any new medications?
No, I haven't injured my knee recently, and I just take a multivitamin and sometimes use ibuprofen for the pain.
Have you noticed any swelling or redness in your knee?
No, there's no swelling or changes in the skin over my knee.
Have you had any recent changes in your weight or activity level?
No changes in my weight or activity level; I just have college scouts watching me play basketball, and my knee pain is affecting my ability to play.
Have you had any family members with knee problems?
No, none of my family members have had knee problems.
Final Diagnosis: Osteochondritis dissecans (OCD)

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A college basketball player complains of worsening pain in his right knee, particularly when going up or down stairs and towards the end of class. The pain started about a month ago and has progressively worsened since then. The patient denies recent knee injury and reports using only a multivitamin and occasional ibuprofen for the pain. There is no swelling or changes in the skin over the knee, and no changes in weight or activity level. The knee pain is affecting the patient's ability to play basketball, and there is no family history of knee problems.
trial_0.vignette_frq: The most likely diagnosis is patellofemoral pain syndrome (PFPS).
